options: A) The v-i relationship at a single port
B) The relationship between input at one port and output at a different port
C) The power dissipated in a resistor
D) The frequency response of the circuit
questions.correctAnswer: B) The relationship between input at one port and output at a different port
questions.explanation: A transfer characteristic relates the output variable (at one port) to the input variable (at a different port). The word 'transfer' means the signal moves from the input port to the output port.

questions.prompt: A driving-point characteristic differs from a transfer characteristic because:
options: A) It involves AC signals only
B) The input and response are measured at the same port
C) It only applies to linear circuits
D) It is always a straight line
questions.correctAnswer: B) The input and response are measured at the same port
questions.explanation: In a driving-point characteristic, both the excitation (input) and the response (output) are at the same port. In a transfer characteristic, they are at different ports.

questions.prompt: For two current-controlled resistors in series with input vi across both and output vo across R2, KCL gives:
questions.explanation: In a series connection, a single current flows through both elements. KCL at the intermediate node forces i = i1 = i2.

questions.prompt: With vi = v-hat1(i) + v-hat2(i) and vo = v-hat2(i), the transfer characteristic vo(vi) is obtained by:
options: C) Eliminating i from the two equations
D) Differentiating vi with respect to vo
questions.correctAnswer: C) Eliminating i from the two equations
questions.explanation: Both vi and vo are expressed in terms of the parameter i. To get vo as a function of vi, you must eliminate i: invert vi = f(i) to get i = f^{-1}(vi), then substitute into vo = h(i).

questions.prompt: When analytic elimination of i is not feasible, the recommended approach is:
options: B) Use the parametric method: compute (vi, vo) for many values of i
questions.correctAnswer: B) Use the parametric method: compute (vi, vo) for many values of i
questions.explanation: The parametric method avoids the need to invert f(i). Choose values of i, compute vi and vo for each, and plot the resulting (vi, vo) points.

questions.prompt: In a series circuit with a PN-junction diode (R1) and linear resistor R2, for vi well above the diode turn-on voltage, vo is approximately:
questions.explanation: Once the diode is fully on, its voltage is approximately pinned at V_gamma. KVL gives vo = vi - v1, and since v1 is roughly V_gamma, we get vo approximately equal to vi - V_gamma.

questions.prompt: For vi below the diode turn-on voltage in the same circuit, vo is approximately:
questions.explanation: Below turn-on, the diode conducts negligible current. Since i is approximately 0, vo = R2 * i is approximately 0 as well.

questions.prompt: For a linear voltage divider with R1 and R2, the transfer characteristic is:
questions.explanation: For a resistive voltage divider, i = vi/(R1 + R2), so vo = R2 * i = R2/(R1 + R2) * vi. This is a straight line through the origin with slope less than 1.

questions.prompt: The slope of the transfer characteristic at a given operating point represents:
options: A) The resistance of the circuit
D) The current through the load
questions.explanation: The slope dvo/dvi at any point on the transfer characteristic curve is the incremental (small-signal) voltage gain at that operating point.

questions.prompt: A nonlinear transfer characteristic (varying slope) implies that the circuit:
options: B) Processes small and large signals identically
C) Processes small and large signals differently, enabling functions like rectification
questions.correctAnswer: C) Processes small and large signals differently, enabling functions like rectification
questions.explanation: Varying slope means the gain depends on the signal level. This is what allows nonlinear circuits to perform rectification, limiting, and other functions that are impossible with constant-slope (linear) circuits.
